text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 7.2.2, TE/GE Closing Agreements, Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System (EPCRS).

Revised and updated IRM 7.2.2.3.1, Early Closing for Certain VCP Submissions, to remove outdated items and to clarify that the individual who makes the decision to close a VCP submission must follow the refund procedures in IRM 7.2.2.10.2, Refund Procedures and Instructions for VCP User
Updated IRM 7.2.2.3.2, Procedures to Fix Errors or Make Updates to Key RCCMS Fields, to that if the screener is a program coordinator then it’s not necessary to discuss with a group
IRM 7.2.2.3.3, Procedures for Correction Disposal of VCP cases on RCCMS, to reﬂect the operating environment in RCCMS and to remove outdated items.
Updated IRM 7.2.2.4, Screening of VCP Cases and IRM 7.2.2.4.1, Screening VCP Cases in RCCMS, to reﬂect current screening procedures.

Updated IRM 7.2.2.6.1, Required Use of Form 5464 (or RCCMS Chronology Tab) And WebETS, to clarify the content that should be entered on the form by specialists and their managers consistent with other functions in Employee Plans and to specify the version of Form 5464 that needs to be used.
Updated IRM 7.2.2.6.2, Check and Update RCCMS Activity Record, to refer to new pre-submission conference requests work and updates made to RCCMS “Fee Types”.
Revised IRM 7.2.2.7, VCP Submissions - Initial Review, to remove outdated items relating to paper based VCP submissions and to add a reference to the new IRM subsection on VCP workpapers.
Revised IRM 7.2.2.8, VCP Submissions-Technical Review Procedure, to add updated references references to Microsoft Teams plus a reference to the new IRM subsection on VCP workpapers.
Added IRM 7.2.2.8.1 Converting a VCP Submission into a VCAP, to add the procedures describing the actions that must be followed if a VCP submission is converted into a VCAP case.
IRM 7.2.2.10, Procedures for User Fee Issues, to add updated references.
Revised IRM 7.2.2.10.2, Refund Procedures and Instructions for VCP User Fees, to remove outdated items, reorganized for clarity, and other miscellaneous changes.
Updated IRM

, Contacting and Corresponding with Applicant and POA Representative, to reference updated policies regarding the acceptance of images of original signatures by fax, the approval to temporarily send or receive documents via email if certain conditions can be met through October
, and to include the requirement that specialists must offer Taxpayer Digital Communication (TDC) when requesting additional information from taxpayers.

Updated IRM 7.2.2.14, Contacting and Corresponding with Applicant and POA Representative, to reference updated policies regarding the acceptance of images of original signatures by fax, the approval to temporarily send or receive documents via email if certain conditions can be met October 31, 2023, and to include the requirement that specialists must offer Taxpayer Digital Communication (TDC) when requesting additional information from taxpayers.

Clariﬁed IRM 7.2.2.16, Dealing With Disagreements and Conference of Right, to provide the rules regarding a possible referral to EP Examinations also apply to cases where a compliance statement may be issued, but one or more failures included with the original submission were withdrawn due a disagreement about correction.
Added new IRM 7.2.2.17.2, Mandatory RCCMS Naming Convention for EP VC Cases, to require ﬁles in RCCMS to be organized and named in a speciﬁc, mandatory way.

Updated IRM 7.2.2.19, Correction by Retroactive Amendment to Resolve Operational Failures, to require the completion of a special retroactive amendment form if correction of an operational failure is being ﬁxed via a retroactive plan amendment to conform the plan’s terms to the plan’s operation.
Revised IRM 7.2.2.24, Closing Procedures for Group Managers, to update the timeframe when a case is to be closed from 5 to 10 days.
Updated IRM 7.2.2.25, Required Use of Standardized VC Letters, to reﬂect changes to official VCP
This supersedes IRM 7.2.2, TE/GE Closing Agreements, Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System (EPCRS), dated October 22, 2021.

) Purpose: This IRM describes the procedures that Employee Plans (EP) Voluntary Compliance follows to process submissions made to the IRS the Voluntary Correction Program (VCP), one of the correction programs in Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System (EPCRS) as currently described in Rev. Proc.
) Audience: EP employees in: EP Voluntary Compliance, Technical, tions, and Examination employees involved in processing VCP submissions. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Employee Plans. (
) Program Owner: Employee Plans. (

) Program Goals: The goal of EP Voluntary Compliance is to provide top quality service by helping them understand and comply with applicable laws, and to protect the public interest by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness to all. (

) EP Voluntary Compliance focuses on encouraging taxpayers (administrators and employers) to: • Comply with income tax laws. • Voluntarily identify and ﬁx problems identiﬁed in administering tax- favored retirement plans. • Protect plan participants and American retirement savings and avoid plan disqualiﬁcation. (
) Certain retirement plans are qualiﬁed if they satisfy the requirements of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) in form and operation. A qualiﬁed plan is to favorable tax treatment. (

) EPCRS is a system of correction programs that encourages sponsors of ment plans to voluntarily correct failures to comply with applicable requirements of the IRC. These programs allow certain tax favored plans to maintain their qualiﬁed status. (
) Types of plans covered by EPCRS include: • Qualiﬁed plans intended to comply with IRC

SCP doesn’t involve the IRS. Plan sponsors use it to ﬁx certain failures when the plan’s operation hasn’t been consistent with its terms or the IRC. Plan sponsors don’t have to ﬁle an application with the IRS. Beginning April

) To help taxpayers ensure they’re taking appropriate actions to ﬁx failures, EP Voluntary Compliance processes VCP submissions and issues compliance statements. In audits of employee plans, EPCRS permits EP to enter into closing agreements with plan sponsors to resolve tax qualiﬁcation failures, avoiding plan disqualiﬁcation. (

) If the plan’s facts and circumstances satisfy a correction program’s eligibility requirements and the plan sponsor/employer corrects the failure per the EPCRS correction principles, the IRS won’t revoke the plan’s tax-favored status. When a plan’s tax-favored status is revoked, affected participants include additional income and plan sponsors are liable to withhold tax due to the failure. (
) EPCRS’s various correction programs, their requirements, detailed principles and other information/instructions are described in a revenue procedure (Rev. Proc.

Tax fraud is deﬁned as an intentional wrongdoing by a taxpayer, with the speciﬁc purpose of evading a tax known or believed to be owed.
Taxpayers who knowingly understate their tax liability often leave evidence in the form of indicators. Fraud indicators are divided into two categories:

Indications of Fraud are a sign or symptom, or signify that actions may have been done for the purpose of deceit, concealment or to make things seem other than what they are. Affirmative Acts (Firm Indications) of Fraud are those actions that establish that a particular process was deliberately done for the purpose of deceit, subterfuge, camouﬂage, concealment, some attempt to color or obscure events, or make things seem other than what they are.
Plans Compliance System (EPCRS) 7.2.2
Don’t pursue fraud unless affirmative acts are present. For examples, see IRM 25.1.1.3, Fraud Handbook, Indicators of Fraud vs. Affirmative Acts of Fraud.
